channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: With Populist Anger Rising, Italy May Be Next Domino to Fall
item.media:description: A demonstrator at a march in Rome on Sunday over a referendum that will be held to overhaul the Constitution.
item.description: Italy could be the next domino to fall as populist anger sweeps through Europe and the United States, upending the political establishment.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: President François Hollande of France Won’t Seek Re-election
item.description: Mr. Hollande stunned the nation with his decision, even though few observers thought he could recover from his poor approval ratings to win next year’s vote.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: A Subdued Vladimir Putin Calls for ‘Mutually Beneficial’ Ties With U.S.
item.description: The Russian leader lamented rising global “fractures,” even in affluent countries, but made no mention of the Kremlin’s efforts to stir up disorder.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Italy’s Constitutional Referendum: What You Need to Know
item.media:description: Posters in Rome urged people to vote yes on Sunday in a referendum on a constitutional overhaul.
item.description: The Sunday vote, which could end up significantly altering the nation’s charter, is a major test for Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, whose political career could hang in the balance.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Afghan Security Crisis Sets Stage for Terrorists’ Resurgence
item.media:description: A funeral near Kabul, Afghanistan, in July, days after two suicide bombers tied to Islamic State attacked a peaceful protest. Western and Afghan officials estimate that about 40,000 to 45,000 militants are active across Afghanistan.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: As the Taliban retake large chunks of territory, they are creating an ungoverned breeding ground for several militant extremist groups.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Hong Kong Government Seeks to Remove 4 More Lawmakers From Office
item.media:description: Supporters of Nathan Law following his campaign for a seat in the Legislative Council in Hong Kong in September. Mr. Law is among four lawmakers the pro-Beijing government says are ineligible to serve.
item.description: The leadership filed papers in court arguing that the legislators were ineligible to serve because they had failed to deliver their oaths as prescribed.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG and MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: He Was a Senior Afghan Government Official. Except He Wasn’t.
item.media:description: An undated photo of Sardar Zmarai in Afghan garb in Panjshir Province.
item.description: The arrest of a serial impostor revealed more than a decade of fraud, audacious even by the standards of Afghanistan, where con artists have flourished in the chaos of war.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and FAHIM ABED

item.title: Myanmar’s Leader Faulted for Silence as Army Campaigns Against Rohingya
item.media:description: Satellite images of two villages in Rakhine State, Myanmar, before and after they were destroyed. The village of Kyet Yoe Pyin, is shown in the images at left on March 30 and Nov. 10, and the village of Wa Peik is shown in 2014 and on Nov. 10.
item.description: Rights advocates accuse Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, a Nobel Peace Prize laureate, of inaction during a brutal counterinsurgency drive against a Muslim minority.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and WAI MOE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Gambia’s President, in Power 22 Years, Loses Election
item.media:description: President Yahya Jammeh at a voting station in Banjul, Gambia, on Thursday.
item.description: The electoral commission officially declared Adama Barrow the winner, an upset victory over Yahya Jammeh, who once said he would stay in power for a billion years if God wanted.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Gambians Choose Between Ruler of 22 Years and a United Opposition
item.media:description: Voters at a polling station in Banjul, the Gambian capital, on Thursday.
item.description: President Yahya Jammeh predicted a decisive win, but his challenger, Adama Barrow, said, “He is not going to be re-elected — his era is finished.”
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Who’s Taping Whom? Paranoia Infuses Brazil’s Scandal-Ridden Politics
item.media:description: President Michel Temer of Brazil in Brasília, the capital, in November. The country’s leaders have been engaged in open political warfare for more than a year.
item.description: Much of the nervousness in the capital, Brasília, stems from a sweeping corruption investigation that, despite a change in administrations, has not gone away.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: In Canada, Feeling ‘Robbed’ of Indian Identity, and Benefits
item.media:description: John Brennick and his cousins face a mountain of skepticism and shifting rules as a claim for recognition as Mi’kmaq, the indigenous nation on Canada’s Atlantic coast, creeps through the Canadian bureaucracy.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: “Indian status” comes with a host of privileges, including tax breaks. But the issue of recognition and who has the right to decide is a complicated one.
item.dc:creator: CRAIG S. SMITH

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Physician-Turned-Artist Offers a Diagnosis for Islam’s Holiest City
item.media:description: The Saudi artist Ahmed Mater created a book of more than 600 photographs to document life in Mecca, Islam’s holiest city.
item.description: In his book, the photographer Ahmed Mater documented Mecca in all its splendor — and squalor — hoping to help steer it away from the rampant commercialism of recent years.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: One Family. Six Decades. Myriad Views of Fidel Castro’s Revolution.
item.media:description: Fidel Castro after arriving in Havana on Jan. 8, 1959. Mr. Castro’s revolution was welcomed by Cubans like Juan Montes Torre, a poor laborer at the time. “It was an emotional shock,” Mr. Montes recalled. “These bearded men, poorly dressed — they won! And on behalf of the lower classes!”
item.description: The clash of emotions common in Cuban families is reflected in a grandfather’s loyalty to Mr. Castro and a granddaughter’s glum view of conditions in her country.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Donald Trump’s Threat to Close Door Reopens Old Wounds in Cuba
item.media:description: President Obama met with the Cuban president, Raúl Castro, in Havana in March.
item.description: In a post on Twitter, he said he would “terminate” the pact President Obama made if Cuba is unwilling to make “a better deal for the Cuban people.”
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE, AZAM AHMED and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Subdued Cuba Prepares Memorial for Castro
item.description: A two-day memorial and a period of “Duelo Nacional,” or national mourning, will offer Cubans a chance to pay their respects to the longtime leader.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Little Fidel in All of Us
item.media:description: People in Miami reacting to the news of the death of Fidel Castro.
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.description: Who would any of us be if he hadn’t rearranged our destinies and caused this rupture in our lives?
item.dc:creator: ACHY OBEJAS

item.title: Fidel Castro, Cuban Revolutionary Who Defied U.S., Dies at 90
item.media:description: Fidel Castro was seen as a ruthless despot by some and hailed as a revolutionary hero by others.
item.description: Mr. Castro brought the Cold War to the Western Hemisphere, bedeviled 11 American presidents and briefly pushed the world to the brink of nuclear war.
item.dc:creator: ANTHONY DePALMA

item.title: What in the World: For Mexico’s ‘Beatlemaniacos,’ All You Need Is Nostalgia
item.media:description: Proyecto Macca, a Beatles tribute band, performing in Mexico City, which is home to more than 50 such bands.
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.description: The Beatles broke up in 1970, but the spirit of the band still thrives in Mexico City, where museum exhibitions, music festivals and cover bands are dedicated to the Fab Four.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Canadian Journalist’s Detention at U.S. Border Raises Press Freedom Alarms
item.media:description: Ed Ou, a Canadian photojournalist.
item.description: Border officials questioned Ed Ou, a freelance photojournalist, and confiscated his phones for a period before denying him entry.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Stanley Rother, U.S. Priest Killed in ’81 in Guatemala, Is Declared a Martyr
item.media:description: The Rev. Stanley Rother during a carnival in Guatemala.
item.description: The decision, announced by the Vatican, could clear the way for the Oklahoma-born son of farmers to become a saint.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: China Exonerates Man It Executed for Murder in 1995
item.media:description: Lawyers for the family of Nie Shubin leaving court in 2014. Mr. Nie was executed for murder in 1995, but another man confessed to the crime in 2005.
item.description: The ruling by the Supreme Court, 11 years after another man confessed to the crime, illustrates the country’s struggle to address inequities in its legal system.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: South Korean Opposition Vows to Impeach Park Geun-hye Next Week
item.media:description: A protester wearing a mask of President Park Geun-hye of South Korea at a rally this week in Seoul, the capital, calling for the leader to step down.
item.description: The embattled president’s party hopes she will agree to resign by April instead, arguing that impeachment would then be unnecessary.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere: Fear, Then Skepticism, Over Antibiotic-Resistant Genes in Beijing Smog
item.media:description: People in Beijing wearing masks this month, after the government declared an orange alert for air pollution, the second-highest level in a four-tier warning system.
item.description: Researchers did not find live bacteria capable of infecting anyone, despite discovering antibiotic-resistant genetic material in the smog.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Andrew Sachs, Hapless Waiter on the BBC Sitcom ‘Fawlty Towers,’ Dies at 86
item.media:description: Andrew Sachs, who played the waiter Manuel in the BBC television series “Fawlty Towers,” in 1981.
item.description: His earnest yet bumbling character, Manuel, was regularly recruited into the schemes of the hotel owner Basil Fawlty, played by John Cleese.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: Zac Goldsmith, Prominent ‘Brexit’ Advocate, Loses Election in London
item.media:description: Sarah Olney canvassed ahead of the Richmond Park and North Kingston by-election, in London, on Wednesday.
item.description: The outcome highlighted some of the rancorous divisions in Britain over its looming departure from the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Trump’s Breezy Calls to World Leaders Leave Diplomats Aghast
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, center, invited President-elect Donald J. Trump to visit his country in a recent call.
item.description: The president-elect’s unfiltered exchanges prompted the White House to urge him to seek the State Department’s expertise in his encounters with foreign leaders.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Common Sense: Trump’s Potential Conflicts Have a Precedent: Berlusconi’s Italy
item.media:description: As prime minister of Italy, Silvio Berlusconi had blatant conflicts of interest, and others tried to curry favor with him by steering business to his companies.
item.description: As prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi kept majority ownership in his businesses. Scandals ensued as those businesses profited and his fortune grew.
item.dc:creator: JAMES B. STEWART

item.title: Mexico’s Central Bank Chief to Take International Post
item.media:description: Agustín Carstens, governor of the Bank of Mexico, announced that he would leave that post in July. He will become general manager of the Bank for International Settlements in Basel, Switzerland. His departure comes as the ascent of Donald J. Trump to the United States presidency has stirred anxiety in Mexico.
item.description: Agustín Carstens, governor of the Bank of Mexico, will leave that post next year to become head of the Bank for International Settlements.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Russian Spacecraft Carrying Supplies Burns Up in Flight
item.media:description: The Progress 65 spacecraft in Kazakhstan on Tuesday. No astronauts were aboard when it failed to reach orbit on Thursday and largely burned up in the atmosphere as it fell back down.
item.description: The cargo ship, which was not carrying any astronauts, disappeared shortly after liftoff, according to Roscosmos, the Russian space agency.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: One of World’s Most Wanted Hashish Smugglers Arrested in Morocco
item.media:description: Ben Ziane Berhili, one of the world’s most wanted hashish smugglers, was arrested in Casablanca.
item.description: The capture of Ben Ziane Berhili was the highest-profile arrest yet in an operation that has seized $3.2 billion worth of hashish since 2013.
item.dc:creator: LORENZO TONDO

item.title: U.N. Apologizes for Role in Haiti’s 2010 Cholera Outbreak
item.description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon avoided any mention of who brought the disease to Haiti, and critics said his mea culpa came too late.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Senate Votes to Extend Iran Sanctions Authority
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, after a Republican caucus at the Capitol on Tuesday.
item.description: Senators said that the vote would help ensure that the United States could quickly reimpose sanctions if Iran violated its obligations under an agreement.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and THOMAS KAPLAN

item.title: Dutch Ask E.U. to Pressure Turkey Over Crackdown
item.description: The Netherlands joined Austria in balking at membership talks with Turkey, which has purged thousands of people after a failed coup effort.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: New King for Thailand as Crown Prince, Vajiralongkorn, Ascends to Throne
item.description: The prince was crowned as King Maha Vajiralongkorn Bodindradebayavarangkun seven weeks after the death of his father, a revered figure in Thailand.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Buzz Aldrin Is Evacuated From the South Pole After Falling Ill
item.media:description: Buzz Aldrin in Australia in November.
item.description: The former astronaut and second man to walk on the moon was flown to a New Zealand hospital and was in “good spirits,” a tour operator said.
item.dc:creator: ERIN McCANN

item.title: Great Barrier Reef Threatened by Climate Change, Chemicals and Sediment
item.media:description: A scientist assessing coral mortality on a section of the Great Barrier Reef in an undated photograph. A new report from the Australian government paints a grim picture of the scale of protecting the 1,400-mile-long reef.
item.media:credit: Andreas Dietzel/ARC Center of Excellence for Coral Reef Studies
item.description: An Australian government report to Unesco says the risks are well-managed, but it also paints a grim picture of the scale of protecting the area.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: Mont Péko Journal: Ousting Squatter Farmers to Save Forest, Ivory Coast Sets Off New Crisis
item.media:description: Workers filling sacks with cocoa beans at an agricultural cooperative in Guiglo, Ivory Coast.
item.description: Squatters using protected land to grow cocoa have helped strip the country of four-fifths of its woodlands. Now evicted, many of them are struggling to survive.
item.dc:creator: SEAN LYNGAAS

item.title: Cyberattacks Strike Saudi Arabia, Harming Aviation Agency
item.description: A version of Shamoon, the virus that hit Middle Eastern energy companies in 2012, was used in mid-November to attack government agencies.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Prince Harry Announces a Scholarship to Serve the Royal Family
item.media:description: Prince Harry inspected the guard of honor after arriving in Bridgetown to commemorate the 50th independence anniversary of Barbados on Tuesday.
item.description: Recipients of the scholarship will spend time in Buckingham Palace, but don’t get the wrong idea: They will cook, cater and otherwise serve the British royals.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Sinosphere: Whistle-Blowing AIDS Doctor Reflects on Roots of Epidemic in China
item.media:description: Dr. Gao Yaojie, who helped expose H.I.V.-tainted blood sales in Henan Province, in her apartment in New York last month.
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.description: Dr. Gao Yaojie, who has tied the epidemic to an unsanitary network of blood sales, discussed what she considers the still-untold truth about AIDS in China.
item.dc:creator: LUO SILING

item.title: Charlie Hebdo, a Lightning Rod in France, Hits German Newsstands
item.description: The satirical newspaper, the target of an attack in 2015 that killed top editors and cartoonists, has started a German edition that features Angela Merkel on its first cover.
item.dc:creator: CHARLY WILDER

item.title: Counterterrorism Law to Let Australia Detain Convicts After Their Sentences
item.media:description: George Brandis, left, the attorney general of Australia, and Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull at Parliament House in Canberra this week.
item.media:credit: Lukas Coch/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.description: The law allows extensions of up to three years for convicts who are judged to be a continuing threat, with no limit on the number of renewals.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: South Korean Arrested After Fire at Birthplace of President’s Father
item.media:description: The burned birthplace of the military dictator Park Chung-hee, the father of President Park Geun-hye, in Gumi, South Korea, on Thursday.
item.description: The fire destroyed part of a memorial to Park Chung-hee, the assassinated dictator and father of South Korea’s embattled president, Park Geun-hye.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Police Confiscate Passports in Parts of Xinjiang, in Western China
item.media:description: Uighurs last year in Kashgar, in the far western Chinese region of Xinjiang. The government, dominated by the Han ethnic group, has tightened control in areas with Uighurs, who are mostly Sunni Muslims.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Residents and online notices reveal no obvious pattern to the restrictions in the region, where ethnic Uighurs have chafed under tightening government control.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In Italy, a Sleeper Crisis for the E.U.
item.media:description: Posters in Rome showing Italian prime minister, Matteo Renzi, and promoting a no vote for the Dec. 4 constitutional referendum.
item.description: Italy might offer proof that the eurozone was made for good times, but not for bad ones.
item.dc:creator: PHILIPP THER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Freedom Party’s Second Chance in Austria
item.media:description: Norbert Hofer.
item.description: The presidential election represents a renewed opportunity for the populist far right to extend its march across the electoral map of Europe.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MISIK

item.title: Editorial: The Great Arch of Chernobyl
item.media:description: The protective shelter over the remains of nuclear reactor Unit 4 at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant.
item.description: A huge steel arch has been moved over the radioactive wreckage of a Chernobyl reactor, a project in which many nations helped to raise funds.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Postscript: One Year Later, a Tip About a Border Crossing Pays Off
item.media:description: Laborers transported ammonium nitrate at the crossing from Akcakale, Turkey, into Syria in April 2015. The compound, a common fertilizer, has been used by terrorists to create explosives.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: How New York Times reporting may have made the Middle East just a little bit safer.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and KARAM SHOUMALI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
